newsitem.title: USA: Kansas wheat damage revised, ratings improve.
newsitem.headline: Kansas wheat damage revised, ratings improve.

text.p: Freeze damage to Kansas wheat is limited to the southern part of the state, and the extent of damage to the rest of the crop appears not to have been as severe as earlier thought, the state's agricultural statistics service said Monday in its weekly crop report.

As of April 27, wheat condition was rated three percent excellent, 52 good, 31 fair, 11 poor and three percent poor. That marked an improvement from last week's report, in which 22 percent of the state's crop rated poor to very poor.
The report pegged damage from the April 12-13 freeze at nine percent severe, 19 moderate, 33 light and 39 undamaged.
That compared to last week's damage rating of 14 percent severe, 26 moderate, 24 light and 36 percent undamaged.
The report said 73 percent of the crop was jointing, ahead of 57 percent last year and on par with the five-year average.
Warmer temperatures during the week ended Sunday allowed the wheat to develop, the report said.
Pasture condition for the state was rated 11 percent excellent, 59 good, 24 fair, five poor and one very poor.
Topsoil moisture levels were listed as eight percent short, 83 adequate and nine surplus. That compared to last week's rating of one percent very short, eight short, 80 adequate and 11 surplus.
